title: 107_hr3011
content: The "Small Business Emergency Relief Act of 2001" may provide loans for disasters that occurred on September 11, 2001. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration may make loans under section 7(b) of the Small Business Act to small business concerns and other eligible entities injured as a result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Special rules apply to these loans, including purposes for repair, rehabilitation, and economic injury, with an interest rate not exceeding 4%. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration may waive certain limitations and requirements for loans made to small business concerns affected by the 9/11 terrorist attacks, including the $1,500,000 limitation on total amount outstanding, credit availability elsewhere, and size standards. The Small Business Administration may waive limitations for loans to small businesses affected by the 9/11 attacks, including size standards. Loans may also be made to charitable organizations. The Administrator cannot make loans under special rules after one year from the enactment of the Act. Loan forgiveness may be granted by the Administrator to small businesses affected by the 9/11 attacks, relieving them of their loan obligations under the Small Business Act. The forgiveness or undertaking of loans must be completed within one year from the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the sale of disaster loans is prohibited. SEC. 4 prohibits the sale of disaster loans made directly or through immediate participation under section 7(b) of the Small Business Act. This includes selling loans through direct sale, loan participations, or including them in asset-backed securities. Definitions under this Act include the Administrator of the Small Business Administration, charitable organization, credit elsewhere, small business concern, and substantial economic injury.
